keyTakeAways: Lance Bass has type 1.5 diabetes, also known as latent autoimmune diabetes of adulthood (LADA).
He uses the Dexcom G7 Continuous Glucose Monitoring System to track his blood sugar levels effectively.
Bass created the online persona 'Blood Sugar Lance' to educate the public about diabetes with humor, developed accidentally through fun content on Instagram.
He identifies white rice and white bread as foods that significantly spike his blood sugar, even with small portions.
His uncle had type 1 diabetes, which influenced his early awareness of the condition and its dietary management.
Advancements in diabetes technology, especially continuous glucose monitoring, have made daily management easier and more manageable.
Stress from his busy career and parenting of twins has an impact on his blood sugar levels.
There is currently no official plan for an *NSYNC reunion tour, and Lance Bass has clarified that recent articles about such a possibility are inaccurate.
Bass emphasizes the importance of community support among diabetics and the positive impact of shared experiences and advocacy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Lance Bass, former member of the boy band *NSYNC, addresses public speculation about a potential reunion tour by stating there is no current plan, emphasizing that fans should not believe all rumors. Instead, he opens up about living with type 1.5 diabetes (LADA), sharing how the Dexcom G7 continuous glucose monitoring system has transformed his daily management. He created the online persona 'Blood Sugar Lance' on Instagram to educate others with humor, highlighting how foods like white rice and white bread can cause dangerous blood sugar spikes. Bass credits both medical technology and community support for making life easier, while also acknowledging that stress from parenting his twins and a busy career impacts his condition. The article underscores his commitment to advocacy and awareness, positioning him as a relatable, authentic voice in diabetes education beyond celebrity status.
title: Lance Bass Has More to Say About Living with Diabetes Than an *NSYNC Reunion
